results.title: Hair
results.creator_credit: CIP Filmproduktion GmbH, United Artists, Lester Persky, Gerome Ragni, James Rado, Michael Butler, Miloš Forman, Ann Roth and Stuart Wurtzel
results.headline_credit: Germany and United States of America, 1979
results.brief_description: Hair is a 1979 musical war comedy-drama film adaptation of the 1968 Broadway musical Hair: An American Tribal Love-Rock Musical about a Vietnam War draftee, Claude, who meets and befriends a tribe of long-haired hippies on his way to the army induction center.

constellations_other.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_other.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

results.creator_credit_for_label: CIP Filmproduktion GmbH, United Artists, Lester Persky, Gerome Ragni, James Rado, Michael Butler, Miloš Forman, Ann Roth and Stuart Wurtzel
results.description: “Hair” is a 1979 musical war comedy-drama film adaptation of the 1968 Broadway musical “Hair: An American Tribal Love-Rock Musical” about a Vietnam War draftee, Claude, who meets and befriends a tribe of long-haired hippies on his way to the army induction center. Claude heads to New York upon receiving his draft notice, leaving the family ranch in Oklahoma. He arrives in New York where he is rapidly indoctrinated into the youth subculture before reporting in for boot camp.
description_for_label: “Hair” is a 1979 musical war comedy-drama film adaptation of the 1968 Broadway musical “Hair: An American Tribal Love-Rock Musical” about a Vietnam War draftee, Claude, who meets and befriends a tribe of long-haired hippies on his way to the army induction center. Claude heads to New York upon receiving his draft notice, leaving the family ranch in Oklahoma. He arrives in New York where he is rapidly indoctrinated into the youth subculture before reporting in for boot camp.

results.title: Hailstones and halibut bones. Part 2
results.brief_description: A sequel to Part 1, produced to illustrate the verses which make up the balance of the poem by Mary O’Neill from her book “Hailstones and halibut bones”. Uses animated drawings to depict the colors blue, grey, orange, purple and brown. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Hailstones and halibut bones. Part 1
results.creator_credit: John Wilson, Sterling Educational Films and Fine Arts
results.brief_description: Celeste Holm reads selections from the poem “Hailstones and Halibut Bones” by Mary O’Neill. Animated drawings illustrate the poem, and show how the writer uses colour to convey feeling. White, gold, red, green and black are each described in a series of couplets. Some of the animated visuals, like the couplets themselves, are literal identifications whilst others reflect emotions and attitudes about colour. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Hailey National Park
results.brief_description: Hailey National Park in India. Visitors are taken through the park on an elephant to observe the wildlife to be found there including reptiles, spotted deer and jackals. No credits available.

results.title: Hail to the chef
results.brief_description: Master chefs from 21 nations compete for gold and silver medals in an eight day marathon focusing on culinary expertise. Each country prepares dishes which are associated with their own nationality.

results.title: Hail Mary = Je Vous salue Marie
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Channel 4, Television Romande and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: This amazingly moving, funny yet disturbing, richly human film has aroused passionate feelings right around the world. Mary, the young daughter of a petrol station owner who is just beginning to discover womanhood, and her taxi driver, Joseph, try to grapple with her unexplained pregnancy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean-Luc Godard, Channel 4, Television Romande and Gaumont-British Instructional

results.title: Haiku dada
results.brief_description: One of 6 works selected by AIM director David Atkinson as representing the best interactive work produced by the AIM centre up until 2004. A wickedly humorous but thoughtful work. Very rich in content demonstrating how animation and interactivity can work seamlessly together. ” Explore the culture and contradictions of Japan. View beautiful woodblock prints in motion, select a haiku. Look into the personal profiles of typical Japanese citizens. Make your own haiku! Loads of fun for the culturally wise or just plain curious. Recommended by four sumo wrestlers out of ten. Basic Japanese and English phrases throughout.”

results.title: Haig: the unknown soldier
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
Scottish field Marshall Sir Douglas Haig is infamous for being known as the man responsible for sending 723,000 British soldiers to their deaths - carnage on an unheard of scale. Inarticulate and stubborn, Haig was accused of being callous and incompetent, the “Butcher of the Somme,” the donkey in charge of the British army of lions. Lampooned and caricatured in the media - print then, television now (BlackAdder). Research by military historians into the performance of the British Army in World War 1 queries the myth of Haig as a buffoon in his position as British Commander in Chief on the Western Front, a post he assumed in December 1915. The program postulates that casualties were high given that it was a war of industrial powers and all that this entailed on a military scale. Provides brief biographical information, readings from Haig’s diary, interviews with historians and veterans and archival footage.

results.title: Haida carver
results.creator_credit: Richard Gilbert and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A young Haida Indian artist shapes miniature totems from argillite, a stone-like jet. Shows the island where he finds the stone, and how he carves it in the manner of his grandfather who taught him the craft. His grandmother shows delight as she polishes each new piece to a gbeautiful black gloss. Weathered monuments stand among the tall firs on Canada’s Pacific coast, where the whittlers used to carve the giant totems.
